DO YOU KNOW WHO'S WATCHING YOU? DO YOU CARE? 

   (ART ADV: Photo is being sent to NYT photo clients. Non-subscribers
can make individual purchase by calling (888) 603-1036 or (888)
346-9867.)  
 (bl)  
 By KATIE HAFNER   
 c.1999 N.Y. Times News Service   

   Call the clothing and outdoor gear company L.L. Bean, don't
identify yourself in any way, place your order, and see what
happens. If you have shopped there before and you're calling from
your home telephone number, the folks there know it _ even if
you've blocked Caller ID. They know where you live. And they have
your credit card number.

   In the course of the transaction, the cheerful sales clerk on
the other end of the line will happily recite that information to
you, letting you dispense with the tedium of digging through your
wallet for a credit card or spelling your street name.

   This is not a new development. L.L. Bean has had such
caller-identification technology in place for years. But the
company began using it openly with customers only recently, in the
belief that they would no longer be spooked, said L.L. Bean
spokesman Rich Donaldson.

   That's not to say that L.L. Bean executives think people are
ready to give up their privacy. To the contrary, L.L. Bean believes
that, as always, people are willing to share private information
with those they trust, and it believes that it has its customers'
trust. The company may be right. It reports that customers love the
convenience. In fact, one recent caller was so charmed by the
personal treatment that she thought the saleswoman recognized her
voice.

   ``That's a trusting relationship with that business,'' said Marc
Rotenberg, executive director of the Electronic Privacy Information
Center, a privacy advocacy group in Washington. Rotenberg said L.L.
Bean's customers had faith that the company would not abuse the
information by reselling it.

   So much for blind faith. Even L.L. Bean recently began
exchanging customers' names and addresses (but not other kinds of
personal information) with other companies, which captures
perfectly the complications and contradictions of a giant policy
issue: What are the acceptable limits to privacy?

   For all the attention it gets, privacy is an elusive concept. It
means something different to everyone, and when it comes to
behavior, both as consumers and as citizens, people draw the line
at different points on the privacy spectrum.

   At one extreme are the privacy fundamentalists, who denounce the
potential abuse on the part of direct marketers and their
increasingly sophisticated personal-profiling techniques. Privacy
absolutists abhor supermarket discount cards and are vigilant about
keeping their names off lists of any kind.

   One person who vigorously guards his privacy is Jason Catlett,
president of Junkbusters, a Web site that helps people protect
their privacy online. He shops on the Web but from a small number
of sites. He also loves the convenience of buying from catalogs,
but he minimizes the number of companies he purchases from so he
can keep a low profile in marketing databases.

   When shopping online and offline, Catlett often renders his
address a little differently so he can track who has sold his name
to others against his instructions. He owns credit cards _ four, to
be exact _ but pays for many things with cash. He steers clear of
supermarket discount cards, which require surrendering not only his
address and telephone number but also, every time the card is used,
details about his shopping patterns. And he never fills out
warranty cards. ``A warranty card is the fast track to junk mail
central,'' he said.

   At the other end of the spectrum are people who simply don't
care who knows what about them. They figure that privacy is a thing
of the past anyway, so why fight?

   Most Americans, however, seem to fall somewhere in between. They
are willing to part with personal information as long as they get
something in return, and as long as they know what is to be done
with the information. They are happy to carry supermarket discount
cards. They are annoyed when they get new computers and must
re-enter all the information needed for one-click ordering at
Amazon.com.

   These same people, however, are highly protective of their
medical records and are generally appalled when they learn of
clandestine data collection practices.

   The recent news, for instance, that Real Networks had been
tracking the musical tastes of people who use the RealJukebox
software to play CDs on their computers generated indignant
messages all over cyberspace.

   Mindy Zuckerman, a freelance producer of corporate events in San
Francisco, is one of those who pick and choose their privacy
issues. Ms. Zuckerman has discount cards from her neighborhood
Safeway and Lucky supermarkets. Both are imprinted with her real
name. Yet when she sends contributions to charities, she includes a
note requesting that her name and address not be distributed. She
occasionally shops over the Internet. And when she called to order
flowers recently from Flowers U.S.A., which she uses frequently,
she was surprised that she was asked for her credit card number.
She assumed the store already had it.

   It bothers Ms. Zuckerman that her Social Security number is her
identification for her health insurance, and she has asked her bank
to use a different means of identification. She doesn't mind the
cameras that record license plates at parking garages. Yet she owns
a shredder, and she shreds anything with her name on it.

   ``I don't imagine people are dumpster-diving in Noe Valley,''
she said, referring to her neighborhood in San Francisco. ``But I'm
originally from New York. Maybe I just brought my paranoia with
me.''

   The idea of privacy as something entitled to legal protection
was most famously expressed in 1890, when Samuel D. Warren and
Louis D. Brandeis, writing in the Harvard Law Review, defined
privacy as ``the right to be let alone.''

   While Warren and Brandeis were more passive, appropriate for
their era, the information age called for a new formulation. In
1967, Alan F. Westin, a privacy expert who is a professor emeritus
of public law and government at Columbia University, gave the
concept a more assertive thrust when he defined privacy in
``Privacy and Freedom'' (Atheneum, 1967) as the right of
individuals to determine for themselves when, how and to what
extent information about them is communicated to others.

   Since Westin came up with that description, the gathering of
information about individuals has become far more widespread and
automatic. Such information is continually being recorded, while
computers are busy merging, purging, sorting and selecting
information to produce personal profiles and pieces of direct mail
that are tailored to consumers' habits.

   What used to be easily protected private information is now
there for the taking, thanks not to changing attitudes but to
changes in technology. Thousands of computers linked to the Web
track individual patterns of online buying and behavior, which are
translated in turn into highly sophisticated marketing strategies.

   ``The World Wide Web is direct marketing on steroids,'' Catlett
said. ``With the Web, the process of gathering information on
consumers and messaging them with new offers is vastly accelerated
in speed and reduced to a very low cost.''

   Privacy advocates say it's fine to be practical like Ms.
Zuckerman, as long as you really know what is being done with the
information you give away.

     
nn

   ``The missing piece here is that consumers aren't always being
told the consequences of all the data collection,'' said Robert
Gellman, a privacy consultant in Washington.

   But people differ in their attitudes toward data collection.
Westin said that for the 25 years or so that he has been conducting
public opinion surveys (occasionally financed by corporations), the
general breakdown of how people draw the line when it comes to
their privacy has remained the same: roughly one-fourth of the
population is vigilant about its privacy, and roughly the same
number of people are indifferent.

   About 55 percent of those he surveys are what Westin called
privacy pragmatists, people who want to know what benefits are in
it for them if they allow information about themselves to be
collected. These pragmatists also want to know what risks they are
running and what safeguards are in place. If they trust the
organization asking for the information, Westin said, they are more
likely to surrender information.

   Rotenberg, of the privacy information center, is skeptical about
those findings, arguing that people's desire for privacy may change
at different times in their lives, or even in the course of a day.
For that reason, he favors legislation that would give individuals
control over the use of their personal information.

   Gellman said supermarket discount cards were a good example of
the kinds of privacy trade-offs many people were willing to make.
Roughly 27,000 food stores in the nation provide cards that offer
discounts or other promotions to customers who sign up; those
customers' personal information can then be linked to records of
what they buy. More than half the customers of those stores have
signed up for the cards, and more are signing up every day,
according to the Food Marketing Institute, a trade group in
Washington.

   ``The supermarket loyalty card is the least intrusive of any
kind of loyalty promotion,'' said Todd Hultquist, an institute
spokesman. ``Stores want a better grasp of what's selling and when,
and when to do certain promotions.''

   Gellman isn't so sure. He said that while preferences in canned
tuna may be fairly innocuous, other purchases may be more private.
``If a woman goes to a supermarket on Saturday and buys a pregnancy
test kit, then buys prenatal vitamins the next week, it's a
reasonable inference that she's pregnant,'' he said. ``And what if
she hasn't told anyone?''

   Jerry Kang, an acting professor of law at the University of
California at Los Angeles, agreed. ``There is widespread ignorance
or misinformation about how personal data is used in the database
marketing industry and in the information collection process in
cyberspace,'' he said. ``Privacy doesn't mean information
quarantine. It just means individual choice. People need to know up
front what will happen to their personal data before they engage in
these market transactions.''

   Catlett of Junkbusters said that was called fair information
practice. ``There is no reason for information to be handled in an
unfair and unsafe manner,'' he said.

   Earlier this week, a group of Internet advertising and
data-profiling companies announced that they would give customers
notice that information was being collected as well as the option
to refuse to have that information used for profiling.

   Catlett, Rotenberg and other privacy advocates say that similar
self-regulatory efforts have failed in the past and that the the
Federal Trade Commission should recommend legislation that would
establish a code of fair information practices, which they say
would include an individual's right to get access to personal
information held by others and would require a person's consent
before such information could be disclosed to others. They also
said online profiling should be halted until legislation is
enacted.

   ``The right to see information about you shouldn't be something
given to you out of the goodness of the company's heart,'' Catlett
said. ``You should have a legally guaranteed right to it.''

   Then there are people like Larry Engel _ so blase on the subject
that they are lost causes to privacy advocates like Catlett.

   Engel, a documentary filmmaker and professor of film at Columbia
University, belongs to the minority of people who are indifferent
about the amount of information known about them. ``I love the idea
of marketers knowing my shopping habits,'' he said. ``And look, if
I'm going to be be spammed on my e-mail, I'd rather be spammed by
people who at least have a clue.''

   Engel loves the convenience of one-click ordering at Amazon.com
and the identification feature at L.L. Bean. He loves it when he
calls the front desk from a hotel room and hears, ``Yes, Mr. Engel,
how can I help you?''

   And the many ways he can be located? ``I don't care if it's the
government or a marketer or my wife, my brother or my accountant _
I'm happy to be located,'' he said. ``Because, the way I look at
it, I don't care if people know where I am. It's my choice as to
whether I respond.''

   Surveillance cameras, Engel said, like those at intersections,
are a bit trickier, but he said that over time, people would
probably not care.

   ``Will a camera on every street corner lead to Big Brother?
No,'' he said, ``it will probably lead to more gossip.''
